repnme.cdata!: China - Yangtze Basin Water Resources Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts were substantial. Lessons are as
            follows. Irrigation projects, and irrigation management
            reforms, based on water supply committees (WSC), and
            farmer's water users associations (WUA), integrated
            into the project as a component, provide large benefits,
            including to poor and vulnerable groups. These benefits were
            demonstrated by the rates of return at completion of
            irrigation subprojects, which were all above appraisal
            estimates, and roughly correlated with the degree of WSC,
            particularly WUA development. Nevertheless, a clear focus is
            required for the main objective - either water resources
            development and management, or, agricultural productivity
            improvement (the former objective is appropriate to a water
            resources project, the latter to a comprehensive
            agricultural development project). In the provision of
            agricultural support to irrigation, it may be more
            effectively implemented at lower levels, even by
            beneficiaries, contracting for the services most required.
            Related to the above, more focused and simplified project
            design, i.e., single agency management control would be
            possible, and more efficient. In addition, multiple
            provinces should not be combined under a single
            Bank-financed project when the components in the provinces
            are widely different, and when there is no central agency to
            coordinate them. There are no economies of scale under such
            circumstances, thus placing a heavy burden on the Bank to
            provide adequate preparation, supervision and coordination;
            instead, a better configuration may have been a separate
            general agricultural development project in Hubei, and a
            water resources project in Hunan, with better results in
            both cases. Most importantly, reduced Bank supervision can
            affect project outcomes, and quality at completion,
            particularly for complex, and/or innovative projects.
